title: Example script
code: # Setup options knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE)  # Clear environment rm(list = ls())  # Load relevant libraries library(modelLong) ##  ## Attaching package: 'modelLong' ## The following object is masked from 'package:graphics': ##  ##     plot ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ##  ##     plot, summary library(dplyr)    # Data manipulation ##  ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ##  ##     filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ##  ##     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2)  # Data visualization  # Load example longitudinal data (must be of long format) ortho <- read.csv("../data/ortho.csv")[-1] ortho <- ortho %>%   dplyr::mutate(Subject = as.factor(Subject)) %>%  # Make subject ID a factor   dplyr::arrange(Subject)  # Arrange measures by subject ortho_labelled <- ortho  # Rename variables for (pretty printing)  ortho_labelled <- ortho %>% dplyr::rename("Distance" = distance, "Age" = age)  # Preview data ortho_labelled[sample(nrow(ortho_labelled), 5),] ##     Subject    Sex Distance Age ## 151     M15   Male     23.0   8 ## 63      F11 Female     28.0  12 ## 102     M06   Male     28.1  18 ## 111     M08   Male     24.5  12 ## 47      F08 Female     24.8  16

title: Authors and Citation
Authors and Citation
text: Hernandez AD (2025). modelLong: Model visualize longitudinal data. R package version 1.0, https://alejandroh3005.github.io/modelLong/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {modelLong: Model and visualize longitudinal data},   author = {Alejandro Dionicio Hernandez},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0},   url = {https://alejandroh3005.github.io/modelLong/}, }

title: Model and visualize longitudinal data
text: package easy visualization modeling longitudinal data. Functions plot repeated measures estimate autocorrelation, marginal effects generalized estimating equations, conditional effects generalized linear mixed-effects models. URL GitHub (.e., source code) : https://github.com/alejandroh3005/modelLong URL Pkgdown webpage : https://alejandroh3005.github.io/modelLong

title: Model and visualize longitudinal data
text: package called modelLong. install, run following code (R): Upon completion, can run following code (R):

title: Model and visualize longitudinal data
text: package depends following packages: dplyr, ggplot2, gtsummary, lme4, geepack.

title: Model and visualize longitudinal data
text: Thank Dr. Kevin Lin kind instruction building R public packages, thanks Dr. Gary Chen teaching methods analyze longitudinal data.

what: Estimate marginal effects with generalized estimating equations — fit_gee
title: Estimate marginal effects with generalized estimating equations — fit_gee
text: Estimate marginal effects generalized estimating equations. Data must long format.

title: Estimate marginal effects with generalized estimating equations — fit_gee
Estimate marginal effects with generalized estimating equations — fit_gee
code: # Load repeated measures of adolescent tooth growth (must be of long format) data <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/alejandroh3005/modelLong/main/data/ortho.csv")[-1]  # Define subject/cluster ID id <- as.factor(data$Subject)  # Fit a GEE model of adolescent tooth growth from age and sex mod_gee <- modelLong::fit_gee(   data = data,   formula = formula(distance ~ age + Sex),   id = id,   family = gaussian(),   corstr = "independence")  # Fitted coefficients coef(mod_gee$fit) #> (Intercept)         age     SexMale  #>  17.5513997   0.4263492   2.7373106   # Full model mod_gee$fit #>  #> Call: #> geepack::geeglm(formula = formula, family = family, data = data,  #>     id = id, corstr = corstr) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)         age     SexMale  #>  17.5513997   0.4263492   2.7373106  #>  #> Degrees of Freedom: 162 Total (i.e. Null);  159 Residual #>  #> Scale Link:                   identity #> Estimated Scale Parameters:  [1] 5.67822 #>  #> Correlation:  Structure = independence   #> Number of clusters:   162   Maximum cluster size: 1  #>

what: Estimate conditional effects with generalized linear mixed-effects models — fit_glmm
title: Estimate conditional effects with generalized linear mixed-effects models — fit_glmm
text: Estimate conditional effects generalized linear mixed-effects models. Data must long format.

title: Estimate conditional effects with generalized linear mixed-effects models — fit_glmm
Estimate conditional effects with generalized linear mixed-effects models — fit_glmm
code: # Load repeated measures of adolescent tooth growth (must be of long format) data <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/alejandroh3005/modelLong/main/data/ortho.csv")[-1]  # Fit a GLMM model of adolescent tooth growth from age and sex mod_glmm <- modelLong::fit_glmm(   data = data,   formula = formula(distance ~ age + Sex + (1 | Subject)),   family = gaussian) #> Loading required package: Matrix #> Warning: calling glmer() with family=gaussian (identity link) as a shortcut to lmer() is deprecated; please call lmer() directly  # Fitted coefficients coef(mod_glmm$fit) #> $Subject #>     (Intercept)       age  SexMale #> F01    16.44088 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F02    17.96976 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F03    18.53544 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F04    19.46805 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F05    17.64869 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F06    16.19626 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F07    18.06149 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F08    18.15322 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F09    15.81404 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F10    13.39842 0.4263492 2.737311 #> F11    21.37915 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M01    20.36644 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M02    15.82568 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M03    17.43100 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M04    18.47064 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M05    16.39137 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M06    18.66939 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M07    15.71866 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M08    16.19261 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M09    17.55331 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M10    21.91060 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M11    16.13146 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M12    17.03349 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M13    17.59918 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M14    17.09465 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M15    18.74583 0.4263492 2.737311 #> M16    15.68808 0.4263492 2.737311 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "coef.mer"  # Full model mod_glmm$fit #> Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod'] #> Formula: distance ~ age + Sex + (1 | Subject) #>    Data: data #> REML criterion at convergence: 648.4082 #> Random effects: #>  Groups   Name        Std.Dev. #>  Subject  (Intercept) 1.974    #>  Residual             1.452    #> Number of obs: 162, groups:  Subject, 27 #> Fixed Effects: #> (Intercept)          age      SexMale   #>     17.5514       0.4263       2.7373

what: Plot repeated measures and autocorrelation — plot
title: Plot repeated measures and autocorrelation — plot
text: Plot repeated measures averages time, autocorrelation measures calculated acf(). Returned ggplot objects may manipulated (multiple facets, additional layers, etc.). Data must long format.

title: Plot repeated measures and autocorrelation — plot
Plot repeated measures and autocorrelation — plot
code: library(ggplot2)  # Load repeated measures of adolescent tooth growth (must be of long format) data <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/alejandroh3005/modelLong/main/data/ortho.csv")[-1]  # Plot the repeated measures and autocorrelation plot_res <- modelLong::plot(   data = data,   outcome = "distance",   time = "age",   id = "Subject",   group_var = "Sex") #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  # View repeated measures plot plot_res$data_plot +   # Adjust labels and x-axis   labs(title = "Repeated measures of tooth growth") +   xlab("Age (years)") + ylab("Distance (mm)") +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(8,18,2))   # View autocorrelation plot plot_res$acf_plot +   # Adjust labels   labs(title = "Autocorrelation of tooth growth") + xlab("Age (years)")

what: Summarize data in a table — summary
title: Summarize data in a table — summary
text: Generate Table 1 style summary data, optional variable stratify descriptions (overall summary statistics always included). Data must long format.

title: Summarize data in a table — summary
Summarize data in a table — summary
code: # Load repeated measures of adolescent tooth growth (must be of long format) data <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/alejandroh3005/modelLong/main/data/ortho.csv")[-1] colnames(data)[3:4] <- c("Distance", "Age")  # Summarize data, stratify by sex, and ensure age is encoded as continuous summary_res <- modelLong::summary(   data = data[-1],  # Ignore Subject ID   group_var = "Sex",   type = list(Age ~ "continuous"))  # View summary table summary_res$table1     Variable       Overall N = 1621                Sex            Female N = 661       Male N = 961     Distance 24.72 (22.50, 26.50) 23.09 (21.50, 24.60) 25.83 (23.50, 27.50)Age 13 (10, 16) 13 (10, 16) 13 (10, 16)1 Mean (Q1, Q3)
